channel.title: Tabletop on Strat
channel.description: Recent content in Tabletop on Strat

item.title: Neoclassical Geek Revival
item.description: An esoteric OSR TTRPG with rules that seem completely unplayable. Despite this, I can see myself picking and choosing certain specific rules and setting details from the book and using them in my own games.

item.title: Monsters, aliens, and holes in the ground
Knave 2e
item.description: The ruleset for my next OSR campaign, Ben Milton strikes again. The tables in this book are a goldmine, so I implemented them on this page here with my own composite rolls for ease-of-use, whether during session prep or at the table.

item.title: Knock #1
item.description: The TTRPG Zine to end all Zines. Filled with great art and essays mostly focusing on OSR play mostly targeted at GMs or roleplayers who want to become GMs.

item.title: Nightmare over Ragged Hollow
item.description: Amazing introductory OSR module for level 1 PCs. This is a great module to run if you’ve never run a tabletop RPG before or if you’d like to introduce new people to the tabletop roleplaying hobby.

item.title: Maze Rats
item.description: The best OSR system for introducing new players to tabletop roleplaying and OSR-style play. Maze Rats’s randomized magic spell system really shines. I recommend strongly encouraging your players to start with at least one spell slot.

item.title: Electric Bastion
item.description: TTRPG with one of the most evocative character creation systems I’ve seen.

item.title: Into The Odd
item.description: A TTRPG stripped of all extraneous parts, leaving you with the only the essential. Seems like a system built for one-shots if you’re willing to put in the effort to support the loosely defined “depressing steampunk” setting.

item.title: Mutants in the Now
item.description: Off-brand Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles TTRPG. Great idea, but seems a little uninspired and too crunchy for its own good. The multiplicative math with percents using non d100 dice is particularly egregious.

item.title: Your Best Game Ever
item.description: The primer on tabletop roleplaying we needed — great for both new and experienced players and GMs and everyone in between.

item.title: Game Master's Handbook of Proactive Roleplaying
item.description:
This book has 25-50 pages of interesting ideas — sadly it’s 239 pages long.

The focus on GMing tips for fantasy games doesn’t help because I’m not interested in tropey fantasy stories told “straight” — most of the book assumes that’s what the reader is interested in.

item.title: Rifts Adventure Guide
item.description: 1/2 systems-agnostic tight and informative GMing essays with contributions from half a dozen GMs dropping knowledge bombs dense with decades worth of GMing experience — 1/2 Rifts-specific stuff that I skimmed through but could be mined for some ideas.

item.title: How to Game Master Like a Fucking Boss
item.description: This book is a trainwreck and I enjoyed watching it crash — even though I would’ve been better off stepping away from it and averting my eyes. But I couldn’t help myself.

item.title: Savage Worlds World Builder & Game Master's Guide
item.description: A bunch of short articles on various Savage Worlds-related topics catering more towards GMs.

item.title: Savage Worlds Adventure Edition
item.description:
Many roleplaying systems claim to support play in any kind of setting but few really do — Savage Worlds is an exception. It’s got crunchy-enough systems that are only as relevant as you want them to be.

Savage Worlds is the most “more than the sum of its parts” tabletop roleplaying system I’ve played — it rocks.

item.title: Savage Worlds: Rifts© - Savage Foes of North America
item.description: A monster manual with some information on opposing factions’s mooks and bigger baddies that PCs can run into working for the Tomorrow Legion. This book also includes a few simple missions that you can run in a pinch or use as a starting point for more complex sessions.

item.title: Savage Worlds: Rifts© - Game Masters Handbook
item.description: The Savage Worlds roleplaying system smashed together with the Rifts Megaverse setting (a post-post-apocalypse kicked off by the cataclysmic return of magic on Earth and the opening of inter-dimensional portals all over it) seems like a match made in multi-planar heaven.

item.title: Savage Worlds: Rifts© - The Tomorrow Legion Players Guide
Troika!
item.description: A wacky absurdist one-shot roleplaying system that would be impossible to improvise but running a premade one-shot might be a lot of fun.

item.title: Apocalypse World
item.description: The tabletop roleplaying game that inspired so many others (through their Powered by the Apocalypse branding) including games I’ve played and enjoyed like Blades in the Dark.

item.title: Sorcerer
item.description: Sorcerer is a tabletop roleplaying game by Ron Edwards. It is an explicit precursor to Apocalypse World, being mentioned in those rules several times (and by extension, all of the Powered by the Apocalypse games).

item.title: Deep Carbon Observatory
item.description:
Dark Avant-garde OSR module that would be a perfect fit for the bleakness of a system and setting like MÖRK BORG.

The PCs will delve deeper and deeper into the madness of a drowning village, a broken dam and an ancient evil that’s underneath it all.

item.title: Kobold Guide to Gamemastering
item.description: A collection of essays about GMing. Offers some good tips and tricks but it’s not as comprehensive or as much of a must-read as So You Want To Be A Game Master?

item.title: So You Want To Be A Game Master?
item.description:
An extremely efficient yet thorough guide to running tabletop RPG games. I would have loved to have read this back when I first started GMing over a decade ago! It’s got everything you need to give you the confidence to start run great games.

Even if you’ve got experience GMing, there’s so much knowledge in this book and it’s expressed so clearly that you’ll undoubtly learn a bunch reading it, no matter what kind of games you’re interesting in running.

item.title: The Lazy DM's Companion
item.description: A tiny collection of punched up blog posts on DMing from Micheal Shea. The “Session Zero Checklist” was useful but there’s nothing here that’s mind blowing or worth going out of your way to read.

item.title: Maze of the Blue Medusa
item.description: An abstract, surreal, mythical, weird sadhouse megadungeon — a perfect fit for old school rennaissance tabletop roleplaying games, as long as you’re open for things to get a little bizarre.

item.title: Shadowdark RPG
item.description: OSR RPG system that cleaned up the Ennie awards in 2024. There’s a succinctness and clarity to the rules which also seems to cover all the bases unlike other OSR systems I’ve read. I’m excited to finally do some old school dungeon crawling with these rules.

item.title: Delta Green - Hourglass
item.description: A Delta Green scenario about a viral video of a woman disappearing in thin air and the small town cult that might be responsible.

item.title: Delta Green - Impossible Landscapes
item.description: A Delta Green campaign module based on the King in Yellow, where investigators start with an investigation into a missing persons case tied to the King in Yellow and get sucked into that world.

item.title: Delta Green - Agent's Handbook
item.description: Lovecraft X The X-Files tabletop roleplaying game. Delta Green has been kicking around for decades and so it has so much modules written for it, critical for an investigative RPG like this where the devil is in the details and it’s much harder to run a game like this without any supporting material.

item.title: Delta Green - Handler's Guide
item.description: Lovecraft X The X-Files tabletop roleplaying game.

item.title: Mothership 1E
item.description: A sci-fi horror tabletop RPG with some of the most evocative RPG modules I’ve ever read. I can’t wait to play this!

item.title: FIST: Ultra Edition
item.description: Metal Gear / A-Team inspired tabletop RPG. Seems like this would be great for one-shots (or potentially longer campaigns) with people with any level of experience in roleplaying because the rules are so simple yet exciting.

item.title: Paranoia: Core Starter Set (MGP50000)
item.description: I’ve played the Paranoia RPG more than a few times, it’s always a blast. If you’re into chaotic, goofy, absurdist, comically dystopian settings and cooperative/competitive roleplaying systems then you’ll love Paranoia.

item.title: The Ultimate Micro-RPG Book - 40 Fast, Easy, And Fun Tabletop Games
item.description: A collection of small one shot tabletop RPGs. Their quality varies and not all of them will be interesting to the people you play with BUT there’s some bangers in here.

item.title: MÖRK BORG
item.description: MÖRK BORG is a pitch-black apocalyptic fantasy RPG about lost souls and fools seeking redemption, forgiveness or the last remaining riches in a bleak and dying world.

item.title: Wicked Ones
item.description: WICKED ONES is a Forged in the Dark tabletop RPG about a group of fantasy monsters building a dungeon, launching raids on the surface to gather a hoard, and pursuing your nefarious master plan.

item.title: Monster Of The Week
item.description: Monster of the Week is a standalone action-horror RPG for 3-5 people. Hunt high school beasties a la Buffy the Vampire Slayer, travel the country to bring down unnatural creatures like the Winchester brothers of Supernatural, or head up the government investigation like Mulder and Scully. It seems OK, nothing extraordinary or unique other than the conceit.

item.title: Heart
item.description: Heart: The City Beneath is a tabletop game about delving into a nightmare undercity that will give you everything you’ve ever dreamed of – or kill you in the process. It is a dungeon-crawling, story-forward tabletop RPG that focuses on what characters have to lose in pursuit of their dreams in the chaotic darkness beneath the world. Weird but in a good way.

item.title: The Extraordinary Adventures of Baron Munchausen
item.description:
A tabletop roleplaying system where everyone tries to one-up each other with increasingly ridiculous stories about their adventures and exploits in their roles as Georgian/Victorian era noble people.

Makes for a great one-shot with the right group.
